metadata.h1: X-Ray Image Classification: The Easy Way
metadata.description: With the rapid improvements being made in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) and the voluntary AI daily digest shared by my fiancé, I thought it was about time to take a deep dive…

all_paragraphs: “AI is going to change the world more than anything in the history of mankind. More than electricity.” — AI oracle and venture capitalist Dr. Kai-Fu Lee, 2018

With the rapid improvements being made in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) and the voluntary AI daily digest shared by my fiancé, I thought it was about time to take a deep dive in and see for myself what it was all about. In particular, I was interested in how I could cleverly integrate AI into product development conversations and how it could be applied to build products that people love. After all, if you don’t know what something is capable of, how can one really innovate with it?

Although I’ve got a Bachelor’s in Computer Science, I’m no expert in AI, ML or deep learning. You don’t need to be an expert either to get started. In this article, I’ll share how to do image classification using neural networks the “easy way”. Note that image classification is different to image detection and image recognition [1]. I’ll start with how to create a data set then this will be used as input to building a machine learning model. Keep in mind that this isn’t the only way, rather it’s a starting point to learn how to do image classification with neural networks, especially if you’re new to the AI space.
Did you know? Deep neural networks are best for conducting image classification.

Before we get into it, here’s a some context to the example that we’ll use. The x-ray images used below are of children. The objective of this image classification project is to help medical professionals to quickly identify children with pneumonia.

A data set is a collection of data. This is a crucial part to get right since it serves as the foundation which your model will be built upon. If it’s not in the data, a model will not learn what it doesn’t know. To train a machine learning model, a high-quality data set is essential because data defines a model’s behaviour and performance.

Going back to our example data set of children x-ray images, it should contain the following:

Besides having a diverse data set with a good variation of positive and negative examples, we also need to have labels associated with each of the examples. If the data set is not already labeled, it will need to get labeled before it can be used as input to building a model. You can either label the data set yourself or pay to get it done.

“In modern artificial intelligence, data rules. A.I. software is only as smart as the data used to train it. If there are many more white men than black women in the system, it will be worse at identifying the black women.” — New York Times

Be sure to watch out for unbalanced data sets — they can introduce unwanted bias in your model. An unbalanced data set is one in which one or more labels has significantly more or less examples than the other labels. Once you have your data set labeled, check the number of examples associated with each of the labels to ensure each label has the same number of examples. If you see that a specific label has only a few examples, whilst the others have around a dozen, you are very likely to observe some bias when the model is used in real world. Once you’re happy with the coverage of the data set, it’s time to build the model.

There are two ways in which a model can be built: (1) automated ML and (2) custom modelling. “Automated ML” is a paid service which means it’s easy to get started and cheap for quick development or prototyping of a model. However, it’s difficult to extend and data that may be sensitive is accessible to the provider. On the other hand, “custom modelling” is completely customisable for unlimited use cases and there is full control over the parameters for tuning the model. But the downside is that it’s expensive to get started and requires machine learning expertise. Online automated ML services, such as Google Cloud and IBD Watson, enable anyone to quickly create models by simply providing a high-quality, labeled data set.

Before we begin to build our model, it’s important to define the business goal(s) and outcomes that we expect from this model. Also have a think about the performance level that you’d like your model to have. As a starting benchmark, we can use human performance on that task. If the model can do it better than what humans can achieve, then I’d say the model is in a decent state. Now, let’s build a model.

As mentioned earlier, the data defines a model’s behaviour and performance, including its efficacy and accuracy. Thus, bad data will result in a bad model. For example, if you feed a model an image that was not represented within the training data, it will not be categorised correctly.

For our X-Ray example we will use Google Cloud AutoML Vision to train a model. We will use an already prepared data set from Kaggle [2]. To get started, upload the labeled data set by clicking “New Dataset”:
Once the data has uploaded, your screen should look something like this:
Next, we’re going to train the model with this data set by going to the “Train” tab and clicking “Train model”.

Note that this data set will automatically be divided up for training, testing and validating the model because the data used to train the model should never be used for testing or validating the model.
Upon the completion of model training, we need to understand “how good” that model is. We’ll take a deeper look into the ways we can analyse the model results, aka outputs.
In order to understand quality of our model we need to to measure its performance. To do that the following metrics are often used:
Going back to where we left off from training the model with AutoML Vision, go to the “Evaluate” tab of the data set to review the model’s performance. It should look something like this:
If you scroll down, you will see more metrics (eg. confusion matrix) and can see the performance measures per specific label as well.

There’s no such thing as training a model once and getting the “perfect model”. It is an iterative process. So in the case that you’re not satisfied with the results, you have two options: 1) improve the data and 2) implement a custom model. I’d strongly suggest that you first look at improving the data and once you cannot achieve any better results, only then consider implementing your own model. At this point, you would have a better understanding of why your model is not meeting expectations. Although having said that, chances are that the model provided by AutoML will get you to a decent point given a high-quality data set.
Finally, let’s see how the model performs with new images. Go to the “Predict” tab and upload an image that was not used in the training/testing data set.
Once the prediction is made, your screen should look something like this:
Congratulations, you’ve just built your first model!
You’re now equipped to give image classification a try for yourself. There’s no better learning than giving it a go yourself.
Note that Google Cloud provides a free trial with $300 credit to get you started. Therefore, it won’t cost you anything.
